captions.text:
Miami is a sub-tropical city located on the
Sunshine State Florida,

in between the Everglades and the North Atlantic
Ocean.

Flying in over Biscayne Bay you can spot the
wonderful beaches

that attract nearly 14 million visitors each
year.
Welcome to Florida’s cultural center
and the diverse mix that represents Miami.

The palm tree-lined city is know for its stunning
beaches,

art deco district, Latin culture, and 24-hour
lifestyle.
It is the place to see and be seen.
Even the zoo residents put on a show!

This is as good as it gets if you are planning
a holiday in the sun.

The weather is warm year-round and the city
has many parks
and some of the best beaches in the country.

Miami is a cultural melting pot that attracts
people from the colder north.

Its mainly Hispanic residents and influx of
South American visitors

add Latin rhythm and Cuban cuisine to the
mix.
Away from the oceanfront,

there is also an artistic, cultural side to
this “Magic City”.

Find theaters on the Miracle Mile in Coral
Gables
and modern art galleries downtown.

Take in the moving sight of the Holocaust
Memorial in Miami Beach
or watch the muralists at work

in the Wynwood Arts District in the city’s
north.

South of the city center stands a century-old
landmark: The Vizcaya Museum.

Step back in time in this opulent mansion
with atrium and gardens
and enjoy idyllic views of the bay.
Across from here is the Seaquarium

where marine mammals will amaze you with their
clever tricks.

This is where Flipper lived, the smart dolphin
from the TV show.

On the other side of the bay are the barrier
islands
that offer everything Miami is famous for:

White sand, palm trees, great tans, and V.I.P.
lifestyle
is what it is all about here.
The star attraction is Miami Beach.

Its bustling promenade, dream cars, sun-adoring
beach lovers

and colorful lifeguard towers have Miami written
all over it.
Touring on a sightseeing bus is a fun way

to see the cultural and architectural hotspots
on the island.
Find hundreds of historic buildings

in the pre-World War II Art Deco district
in South Beach,

which you can call SoBe once you are in the
know.

Take some time to stop at Lincoln Road Mall
to browse the shops and markets.

On your way back to the mainland visit Jungle
Island

where inquisitive wild cats and Florida’s
iconic pink flamingos
are curious to meet you.
Closer to the Everglades is another lush zoo,
but this one is mainly for primates.

Monkey Jungle’s residents love hauling up
the food you leave them

and even collect treats from your outstretched
hands.

If you are lucky you may receive some hugs
and kisses as a reward.
Also near the Everglades is Zoo Miami.

Its has cageless habitats with only a moat
between you
and the local species and more exotic animals.

If you feel active, paddle over the bay around
Key Biscayne,
or bike along Crandon Boulevard.

In between activities you can lounge on the
beach.

Miami is one of those dream destinations that
appeals to everyone.
Its beach- and party culture attracts singles,

while couples will find romance in the al
fresco restaurants
and on the boulevards.
And thanks to many fun attractions,

Miami also gets the thumbs up from families
with children.

If you are in search of a good time in the
Sunshine State,

come to Miami to explore its long stretches
of beaches,

family-friendly zoos and famous art deco district
any time you like!

comments.text:
Some areas of Miami can be dirty because of litter.  I've read many 
complaints about the litter and trash in Miami.  People in Miami need to 
clean up the litter.  Almost everyone in Miami is of Cuban descent.  Miami 
is like a Latin American country because of that.  Spanish is a popular 
language in Miami.  I would love to live near the beach someday, but I 
don't think I would enjoy living in a big city like Miami.﻿
comments.author: Brian Cook

comments.text:
I def prefer Fort Lauderdale. Just as much stuff to do and the traffic 
isn't anywhere near as bad. Driving around Miami Beach on a Sat or Sunday 
is a pain in the ass. Go grab a Corona at the Clevelander on S. Beach and 
see how expensive that is. Miami Beach is over rated, over priced, over 
crowded and nothing special. Pretty water and the sand is nice but thats 
all over south Florida. ﻿
comments.author: soflo23

comments.text: +soflo23 Toronto, Canada. right now in Ottawa, the Capital for my Masters.
comments.author: halfvolley11

comments.text: +halfvolley11 Where you from?
comments.author: soflo23

comments.text:
+soflo23 Okay Houston is not the most important economic centers. But there 
are lots of jobs in Houston Area. It has no reason to be famous. But the 
economy is huge. That is what I meant. Houston Dallas Boston are similar in 
terms of job and business opportunities. Miami is probably close or equal. 

My grandfather's brother lives there. He says tax is cheap and its mad easy 
to make money. Oil Industry is huge over there. Plus there is NASA and 
stuff.
comments.author: halfvolley11

comments.text:
+halfvolley11 Nope. Im a white boy through and through. There is a heavy 
Cuban influence in Miami proper but you're starting to see a lot of South 
American influx as well. My wife is Colombian for instance. Cubans and 
Colombians were really the ones who built the city and surrounding area 
with the drug money that came through. Before the late 70's Miami was just 
a retirement city with great fishing and nice beaches.

Miami is popular from the 80's drug thing. A lot of music and TV shows made 
Miami and Miami Beach what it is. Once the fashion industry found South 
Beach than it was all over. 

Houston you say? Never really thought Houston was well known. I know its a 
decent size city but not really famous for anything.
comments.author: soflo23

comments.text:
+soflo23 Lol, the David Bekham story sounds hilarious.  He is a rich 
spoiled soccer star brat. But the point is, there is a big name for Miami. 
When you are going to be selling the whole region for sports team or 
anything, including Fort Lauterdale, it is selling because of the Miami 
brand name!! You see, there is a value for it. Its known all over the world 
for some reason. Like for business purpose, no offence but its not as 
important as Chicago, LA, San Fransisco or Houston but its probably very 
very famous. So the whole region, instead of fighting should get more 
united. 

I heard there is a lot of Cuban influence. Are you of Cuban background as 
well?
comments.author: halfvolley11

comments.text:
+halfvolley11 Dude. Lol. You're saying what I've been preaching for years. 
Broward used to be Dade and Palm Beach back in the late 1800's and early 
1900's until they both gave up land to form Broward. I think they don't do 
it because of management issues and money and so on.

A lot of people from Dade hate people from Broward and vice versa. Im from 
Broward and I was having a conversation with a friend of mine last night 
about Miami. He's ranting and raving that Miami is the worse city in the 
country and that nobody speaks English etc. etc. For whatever reason, 
theres strong feelings when it comes to these counties. I  love Miami minus 
the traffic and the expensive entertainment. It would be great though to 
combine the areas and just call it: MIAMI

David Beckham wants an MLS team here and they were talking about putting it 
in Hollywood. DB shot it down because he wants the "Miami" tag to it. How 
stupid.
comments.author: soflo23

comments.text:
+soflo23 Why not amalgamate the entire region or at least the populous 
dense region , incorporate it, make 1 public transport company  for it, 
Miami transit, 1 police department for that big region, 1 sports team for 
the region, make it more centralized and give a BIG city status. No Miami 
beach or whatever. Only Miami. Miami sells from hollywood to India to 
Russia to everywhere man. Miami Heat is famous  globally. Why not 
amalgamate and make it even better?
comments.author: halfvolley11

comments.text:
+halfvolley11 Right, but the metro area is considered all of south Florida. 
Miami isn't considered a major city but wants that title. They want the 
title but they aren't willing to share the credit with the other two 
counties. The same two counties who could technically give them that 
status. However, Miami and Dade in general choose to separate themselves 
from Palm Beach and Broward for some reason
comments.author: soflo23

comments.text:
+soflo23 Thats what I meant. Miami should be considered as a big city. 
People go by metropoliton area.
comments.author: halfvolley11

comments.text:
+halfvolley11 Miami isn't really a major city when compared to NYC, 
Chicago, or LA. But the Miami metropolitan area should be the tri country 
area making it a "major city".
comments.author: soflo23

comments.text:
+soflo23 Come on man. Do not go by city boundary definition.  By city 
boundary, they only named pretty much the downtown Miami as Miami city and 
rest with different names. Imagine if you named Manhattan as New York and 
separated Bronx, Brooklyn and Queens from New York City. On paper and by 
your definition New York city would sound so puny.  Dont take the credit 
out of Miami just because Miami is not fully amalgamated or incorporated. 
You need to support Miami to give it a big city status like New York, 
London, Chicago, LA, etc. If you divide it, it will loose its spark.
comments.author: halfvolley11

comments.text:
+halfvolley11 Fort Lauderdale and Broward County has about 2 million 
people. Miami and Dade has about 3. The Miami metropolitan area (Dade, 
Broward, Palm Beach) has about 6-7 million people. Fort Lauderdale is a 
semi large city and part of large metro.
comments.author: soflo23

comments.text:
+soflo23 yeah but we are talking about big cities here. Fort is not a big 
city.
comments.author: halfvolley11

comments.text:

Chicago and I took him and my wife to the Clevelander for some drinks. I 
bought a few Coronas and the bill was $60. Friggin ridiculous! The people 
there are douchey and traffic is a nightmare. I guess if you've never been 
to Miami though you would have to go at least once. I was at Hollywood 
beach yesterday. World of difference.

comments.text:
I've lived here for 13 years of my life. My first home in the US when I 
left South America as a child, lived here for 11 left to the service and 
was stationed in Japan then came back when I was done and been here 2 more 
years. I love the hot weather, the beaches, and occasionally the night 
life. The opportunity for jobs is decent but the cost of a house here is 
too much in my opinion, Miami is great for vacations though. I do plan on 
moving when my lease is up on March 2015 either to San Antonio, San Diego, 
or Seattle anyone who's lived in those places can tell me their 2 cents? 
Thanks﻿

comments.text:
+The Jackal You get me right? I mean, if you wanna go and see dolphins or 
whales, go and book a seat on a charter boat that will take you out to sea; 
it's still damaging to their habitat but at least they're free. I went to 
one aquarium in Tokyo and I'll admit it was somewhat entertaining but I 
couldn't help feeling guilty afterwards that the dolphin is getting shoved 
back into a tiny pool outside as soon as we left. 

I went on a charter boat in New Zealand, in the Bay of Islands and there 
were literally dozens of dolphins swimming alongside the boat for the 
majority of the trip. It was amazing, and seeing them in their natural 
environment was so heartwarming.

I would rather see most animals in their natural environment; with the 
possible exception of people like Mr. Oliver, whose 'natural environment' I 
dread to imagine...

;)
comments.author: Snakebloke

comments.text:
This is a nice video.  I've been to Disney World and some of the beaches in 
Florida.  This looks like Florida to me.  It's usually hot near Orlando. 
 Florida doesn't really have four seasons.  Florida has long, hot summers 
and brief, mild winters.  Florida is very flat.  There are no hills or 
mountains anywhere.  I've never been to Miami, but it looks like a nice 
city to me.  I would choose Miami over Atlanta.﻿
